The understanding about family

When we are able to spend time together as a family on a daily basis, it may seem as though we are encountering a solid and well-defined concept. However, as Kathleen Gough observes, the exact origins of families remain uncertain. It is speculated that they emerged approximately "two million and 100,000 years ago" (Gough, Kathleen, 1971, 760). The development of the family concept also took time to crystallize, as evidenced by research on Frederick Engels' work (Engels, Frederick, 1944):

  • Until the year of 1860, there was not any study about the history of the family, the sciences still embracing ideas derived from the Pentateuch (Engels, Frederick, 1988, 708 ; Torah, Neviim u-Khetuvim. Twenty-four books of the Holy Scriptures carefully translated according to the Massoretic text, on the basis of the English version, after the best Jewish authorities, 1891, pp. 1 - 254 ).
  • Among indigenous American, African, and Australian societies, "kinship" model prevailed. Deeper investigation led to the conclusion that prior to the establishment of patriarchal societies, matriarchal societies were prevalent (Engels, Frederick, 1988, 709, 710 ; Engels, Frederick, 1944, pp. 91). Another illustration of the significant role of women, along with the presence of kinship relationships, is evident in the Inca Empire (History Tracers, 2024 ; Poma de Ayala, Felipe Gusmán, 1615, pp. 121 - 140).
  • According to Morgan, our species developed four distinct types of families (Engels, Frederick, 1988, pp. 712 - 719):
    1. The Consanguine Family: Considered the earliest form, where all members are descendants of a single couple, making everyone both siblings and spouses.
    2. The Punaluan Family: Initially marked by the absence of parent-child relationships, followed by the exclusion of sibling relationships.
    3. The Pairing Family: Men had a primary wife with whom they cohabited, along with additional wives who did not have the freedom to take additional partners. Divorce was relatively simple, with children typically remaining with their mother.
    4. The Monogamous Family: This model features a nuclear family structure consisting of a father, mother, and children.
  • Regarding monogamy, it's important to note that it wasn't initially driven by romantic love or natural instincts, but rather by economic considerations. While the Romans provided relatively favorable treatment of women compared to the Greeks, significant advancements in the institution of marriage occurred with the Germanic peoples. The love as a basis for marriage did not become prevalent until the European Middle Ages (Engels, Frederick, 1988, pp. 719 - 729).

Frederick Engels delineates three social strata within human (Engels, Frederick, 1944, pp. 19 - 25). When discussing the Iroquois Indigenous peoples, he notes their adherence to what he terms 'primitive family' strutcutres, akin to those observed in ancient Greek and Romans societies, which he suggests "common to all barbarians until their entry into civilization" (Engels, Frederick, 1944, pp. 86, 101 - 102). However, it's necessary to recognize that such classifications shouldn't imply superiority or inferiority among peoples, but rather underscore the diversity of human thought and culture (History Tracers, 2024). While there are indeed instances of behaviors associated with 'barbarism,' they may not align with the specific context of Engels' observations. Thus, we refrain from discussing them here.

Reflection 1: About families
In the study of Frederick Engels' work (Engels, Frederick, 1988), four distinct types of families are presented. How many types of families were you familiar with before?
 

In a recent paper, Sergio Reuben Soto elucidates our understanding of the evolution of the concept of family. He explores the influence of various relationships on Homo sapiens and concludes that modern society has a distinct impact on the familial nucleus (father, mother, and children), presenting a conclusion contrary to conventional wisdom (Soto, Sergio R., 2006, pp. 12).

Questions

    Answer next questions:

  2. Was the family model in América/Abya Yala different of monogamy? .
  3. Does Morgan mention four different family kind? .
  4. Did women have a major role in Indigenous families? .
